sen.j: 木津川駅（きづがわえき）は、かつて京都府京田辺市（当時田辺町）の奈良電気鉄道線→近鉄京都線上に存在した臨時駅。
sen.e: The Kizugawa Station was a temporary station once existed on the Nara Electric Railway Line, later Kintetsu Kyoto Line, in Kyotanabe City (Tanabe City at that time), Kyoto Prefecture.
Kizugawa Station was a temporary station that once existed on the Nara Electric Railway Line (later the Kintetsu Kyoto Line) in Kyotanabe City (Tanabe City at that time), Kyoto Prefecture.
Kizugawa Station was a temporary station that once existed on the Nara Electric Railway Line (later the Kintetsu Kyoto Line) in Kyotanabe City (Tanabe City at that time), Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 富野荘駅～新田辺駅間に設置され、木津川_(京都府)の南側、新田辺車庫のやや北に位置していた。
sen.e: The station was located between the Tonosho Station and the Shintanabe Station, to the south of the Kizugawa River (Kyoto Prefecture) and slightly to the north of Shintanabe Shako.
The station was located between Tonosho Station and Shintanabe Station, to the south of the Kizugawa River (Kyoto Prefecture) and slightly to the north of Shintanabe Shako.
The station was located between Tonosho Station and Shintanabe Station, to the south of the Kizu-gawa River (Kyoto Prefecture) but slightly north of the Shintanabe Shako depot.
sen.cmt: Kizu-gawa River, Shintanabe Shako depot としました。

sen.j: 京都市は海から遠く、海水浴へ行こうにも長時間列車に揺られて日本海側や紀伊水道などへ向かう必要があった。
sen.e: As the Kyoto City being far from the sea, people had to ride on a train for a long time to go for a bathe in for example, the Japan Sea or Kii-Suido (Channel).
Given Kyoto City's location far from the sea, people had to ride a train for a long time in order to bathe in for example, the Japan Sea or the Kii-Suido (Channel).
Given Kyoto City's location far from the sea, people had to ride a train for a long time in order to bathe in for example, the Japan Sea or the Kii-Suido (Channel).

sen.j: そのため、琵琶湖と木津川に置かれた水泳場が人気を集めることになった。
sen.e: Accordingly, places to swim provided at Lake Biwa and Kizugawa River became popular.
Accordingly, the places to swim provided at Lake Biwa and the Kizugawa River became popular.
Accordingly, the swimming areas provided at Lake Biwa and the Kizu-gawa River became popular.

sen.j: 近鉄京都線の前身となる奈良電気鉄道は、1929年（昭和4年）に木津川へおよそ3.3万m²に及ぶ水泳場が開設されたのに伴い、同社線が川を渡って直ぐの所に仮設ホームを設け、水泳場へのアクセス機関とした。
sen.e: The Nara Electric Railway, a predecessor of Kyoto Kintetsu Line, built a temporary platform just across the Kizugawa River for access to places to swim when the area of about 33,000 m² opened for the places to swim at the Kizugawa River in 1929.

The Nara Electric Railway, a predecessor of the Kyoto Kintetsu Line, built a temporary platform just across the Kizugawa River for access to places to swim when the area of about 33,000 m² opened in 1929 to provide swimming at the Kizugawa River.

The Nara Electric Railway, a predecessor of the Kyoto Kintetsu Line, built a temporary platform just across the Kizu-gawa River for access to swimming areas when the area of about 33,000 square meters opened in 1929 to provide swimming at the Kizu-gawa River.
sen.cmt: Kizu-gawa Riverとしました。M² は square meters としました。

sen.j: 駅の性格から夏季のみ開設される臨時駅であって、後に一旦常設駅となるも、戦時中は一旦廃止されて戦後すぐに復活した。
sen.e: The station was a temporary station open only during summer; it later became a permanent station for a while, and was abolished during the war time, and then reopened immediately after the end of the war.

The station was a temporary one that was open only during summer, but later it became a permanent station for a while; it was abolished during the war but was reopened immediately after the end of the war.

The station was a temporary one that was open only during summer, but later it became a permanent station for a while; it was abolished during the war but was reopened immediately after the end of the war.

sen.j: 最盛期の昭和30年（1955年）度には、年間約17万人もの人が電車使用でこの水泳場を訪れたという。
sen.e: In 1955 at its peak, as many as 170,000 people annually visited the places by using the train.
In 1955, at its peak, as many as 170,000 people annually visited these places by riding the train.
In fiscal year 1955, at its peak, as many as 170,000 people annually visited these places by riding the train.
sen.cmt: In fiscal year 1955 としました。

sen.j: その後、プールなどの施設が各地にでき、水泳場の意義も薄れたことから、1965年（昭和40年）の閉園と共に駅も休止され、9年後に正式廃止となった。
sen.e: Then, due to the construction of facilities including swimming pools around the country, the place to swim came to be of less significance, thereby the station was closed as the places to swim were closed down in 1965, and the station was officially abolished nine years later.

Then, due to the construction of facilities (including swimming pools) around the country, the place to swim came to be of less significance; consequently, the station was closed since the swimming areas were closed down in 1965, and nine years later the station was officially abolished.

Then, due to the construction of facilities (including swimming pools) around the country, the place to swim came to be of less significance; consequently, the station was closed since the swimming areas were closed down in 1965, and nine years later the station was officially abolished.

sen.j: 1929年（昭和4年）7月10日 水泳場の開設と共に開業
sen.e: July 10, 1929: The station opened as the places to swim opened.
July 10, 1929: The station opened as the places to swim opened.
July 10, 1929: The station opened as the places to swim opened.
In 193X, the station became a permanent station.
In 193X, the station became a permanent station.
193X: The station was upgraded to permanent status.
May 20, 1945: The station was closed.
May 20, 1945: The station was closed.
May 20, 1945: The station was closed.
On October 1, 1946, the station was abandoned.
On October 1, 1946, the station was abandoned.
October 1, 1946: The station was abolished.

sen.j: 1948年（昭和23年）7月1日 臨時駅として再開
sen.e: July 1, 1948: The station was reopened as a temporary station.
July 1, 1948: The station was reopened as a temporary station.
July 1, 1948: The station was reopened as a temporary station.

sen.j: 1963年（昭和38年）10月1日 奈良電気鉄道が近畿日本鉄道に合併
sen.e: On October 1, 1963, the Nara Electric Railway was merged into the Kintetsu Corporation/Kintetsu Railways.
October 1, 1963: The Nara Electric Railway was merged into Kintetsu Corporation/Kintetsu Railways.
October 1, 1963: The Nara Electric Railway was merged into Kintetsu Corporation/Kintetsu Railways.
August 23, 1965: The station was closed.
August 23, 1965: The station was closed.
August 23, 1965: The station was closed.
On July 20, 1974, the station was abandoned.
On July 20, 1974, the station was abandoned.
July 20, 1974: The station was abolished.
Kintetsu Kyoto Line
Kintetsu Kyoto Line

sen.j: 富野荘駅 - 木津川駅（臨） - 新田辺駅
sen.e: Tonosho Station - Kizugawa Station (temporary) - Shintanabe Station
Tonosho Station - Kizugawa Station (temporary) - Shintanabe Station
